title: Eagle Pack
content:
I have tried myfonts and identifont and have had no luck. Can someone help me here? Thank you! ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071221093542im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/33575.jpg)

 [‹ (x) "Latin" script font from "13 Ghosts" - Ex Ponto (backslanted) {Yves}](http://web.archive.org/web/20071221093542/http:/www.typophile.com/node/4259 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Typefaces: technical drawing - various {gang} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071221093542/http:/www.typophile.com/node/4319 "Go to next forum topic")
author: julia

comments.content: What is the source of the image? This looks like something made from one of those engraver tools used to make license plate frames (the rounded ends of all the strokes are characteristic of those devices). If that is the case, this is based on a template, and not a computer font.

It reminds me of a transfer face called Bogart, but I cannot find it online, does anyone have an old Letraset (or similar) catalogue?   
   
There's also a similar one called Flanders, but I don't remember it having rounded ends.   
   
It's definitely not Eric Olson's [Bryant.](http://web.archive.org/web/20071221093542/http:/processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/bryant/index.html)
Theres nothing close to it in either the Letraset or Mecanorma catalog, except for Letraset's Cut-in Medium. But the 'g' doesn't match and the 'e' is open. Still looking...
Zipatone had a face called 'Bogart' in dry transfer. That must be the one you're thinking of Jesús, but I can't seem to locate a copy of it anywhere
I am not sure where this came from. I am recreating it for a client and was hoping it was a font! Looks like I will be redrawing it, but thank you for all the help!
